This plugin still uses nova-network security groups clients. These clients are no longer provided in tempest and are replaced by neutron clients[1]. Since these clients use different rulesets notations, simple substitution won't work.
You can either:

1. Keep nova-network security groups clients until all security groups related methods are cleaned up and then cleanup the rest of setup_clients method

2. Keep setup_clients method until all security groups related methods are cleaned up and then remove setup_clients on top of that (probably the cleaner way)

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/bbc9dd34f6455aa7fdd70737764408e48c1494f8

thanks, the waiter fixes the race condition, +2

situation which is avoided by the waiter:
1. delete_namespace is called as part of the test
2. test execution continues -> cleanup is executed
3. delete_namespace is called again as part of the cleanup
4. for whatever reason the service serves first the second delete_namespace call (which was done as part of the cleanup)
5. namespace is deleted by the cleanup, not by the test case which results in 404 for the delete_namespace call from the test case
6. test case failed

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: This patch is actually hiding the issue reported in the bug. The metadata proxy won't be bind to any port, in this case the IPv6 metadata IP address. The fix for this problem is being addressed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/820897, stopping the multiple subnet "crosstalk" that leads to the dadfailed status.

I could "fix" the namespace connectivity but is not fixing what is broken here and the metadata agent won't have connectivity. As commented, this patch is hiding the real issue just to prevent the DHCP namespace to be recreated. NetworkCache is updated accordingly to the status of the DHCP namespace. If we have an error, as reported in the bug, the cache reflects this. If the metadata agent is not working, the DHCP namespace is not in healthy state.

[1] is the proper fix for this error.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/820897

Thanks for clarification, I got it now. You are ok, that when exception occurs let's delete namespace and after restart it'll be recreated. From developer point of view it makes totally sense. Problem I have is that it is not how it behaves and I do not see from the code that this is the intention of someone who wrote the code (no call of deletion of namespace after unusccesful call of update_isolated_metadata_proxy). DHCP namespace is not deleted when exception occurs or when dadfailed happens, but much much later, could be months after dadfailed issue.

Let me please explain it from cloud Operator point of view, what is real behavior:

To trigger the bug, we needed to restart dhcp agent when existing namespace is already in dadfailed state. Then you could see that duplicate address Exception is raised. Even after exception was raised everything worked normally on ipv4 (metadata/dhcp/everything) level, as I wrote, for several months on some networks (depends on tenant activity). We have seen that exception in logs, but as we do not use ipv6 we did not bother with that as everything looked working good for several months. Then if in such network user creates VM (probably any modification of neutron port can triggers that), then dhcp agent silently deletes whole namespace. No message in INFO level of logging. Only after turning on debug level there is a message in log:

2022-01-01 08:17:52.841 7 DEBUG neutron.agent.linux.dhcp [req-07bf64cd-521a-4b75-b6ca-47d7b13cc9ce - - - - -] Killing dnsmasq for network since all subnets have turned off DHCP: d86b1ff7-1517-41f4-86e8-a07c97b04556 reload_allocations /var/lib/kolla/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py:586

As you can see dhcp agent thinks that all subnets have disabled DHCP, but it is not true. Network has subnets with dhcp enabled.

Then one user after another were creating incidents on support team, that VMs are not reachable as leases on VMs expired one by one. Even from debug logs we were not able to troubleshoot why namespaces  were deleted (subnets had dhcp enabled and were assigned to network). We had to add more log messages and found out, that NetworkCache is incorrectly populated (missing subnets) and therefore dhcp agent thinks that namespace should be deleted. So dhcp agent did not delete the namespace because of duplicate address exception, but several days/weeks/months later because we restart dhcp agent and NetworkCache was incorrectly populated.

I completely understand that fixing the bug 820897 will solve that particular one bug with dadfailed interface, but this change-set fixes bug with NetworkCache update. Bug 820897 just caused to show that bug.

Maybe it would be good to create dedicated bug for the behavior which I'm describing here and we can discuss it there where I can attach real logs from production. What do you think? Would that be better way to go?

Sorry for so long response.

I do not think it hides the issue. Operator still can see exception in the log as ERROR and in this particular case ipv6 metadata won't work, so it won't be hidden. But bug will be localized on particular dhcp feature, like only ipv6 metadata connectivity in this case and nothing else.

What it fixes is that dhcp namespace and connectivity to all existings VMs in such network won't be lost if any exception happens before update of NetworkCache, because NetworkCache will be always in correct state. The "stop" is supposed to be graceful, if that doesn't work by the timeout, crictl does a force kill. I didn't have any other forceful utility I thought I should call here, so thought it was OK in this shell pipeline even without checking return code -- there isn't anything more I can do.

Regarding the logging. There is another service timing issue here Chris and I have been discussion that we want to correct, but not with this update.

We want like to enforce a service dependency of containerd.service before kuebelet.service on start, and reverse order for stop.  Right now there is a race.  The logger service itself will shutdown before the containerd.service is fully stopped.  So what happens is that some of the logs come out, and the rest *vanish* and you won't see "Stopping all containers completed."

Should open a separate LP for that issue.

Need to check why removing port in parallel is actually slower than removing sequentially.
The reason was, that it didn't wait for the results for port deletion - greenpool has been fed with the tasks, but there was no waiting for the results.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I think the decision on whether or not to proceed with this option basically boils down to "are editable installs a required feature". And if they are we end up pivoting to the global venv anyway which solves this problem differently.

IMHO, editable installs are definitely required for as long as we can reasonably support them. Devstack is not a deployment tool, it's a development and testing tool. It need not (IMHO) adhere to proper security hygiene (nor does it *at all* currently) in the same way any real deployment tool should. It needs to facilitate our testing and development practices, and editable installs are very much part of that. Working on a live install will be substantially more laborious without editable installs, so I'm strenuously opposed to losing that functionality unless we just entirely can't get past it. If upstream python stuff makes it massively more difficult in the future, then we'll have to evaluate our options, but until that point, I don't want to lose this functionality.

I'm also not really sure how venvs get us around a general limitation on editable installs in the future. If it's just to get around having something installed in the system and editable as a normal user, I'd argue that, again, that's really not a concern (rather, it's a feature to me). But, if that's what we have to do to keep things editable, then so be it.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Just adding my opinion in here, but I definitely think losing editable installs is a major (major) problem.

inc/python.message: Out of curiosity why not `pip wheel ./` or similar then install a wheel? This has the benefit of not relying on outdated methods (setup.py sdist) and doesn't require we install an additional tool (build).

We need wheel installed somewhere, but maybe we already have it. We don't have build installed for sure though. I'll give wheel a shot in hopes it's available to the interpreter already, otherwise we'll need to add more code to install it.
Is it not valid to do `pip install 'foo.tgz[bar]'`? https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52228286/how-to-pip-install-with-wheel-specifying-extras indicates this is valid with wheels at least.

Oh, perfect. Yeah I simply left it out for now so as to simplify the PoC and avoid confusing matter by guessing about how to do extras with a local archive. In retrospect, I don't see any good reason it shouldn't work.
I think these quotes may have ended up in the wrong spot?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Also note that I think this solution is superior to some other attempts (i.e. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/837731) because it keeps things behaving the way they have been for users of devstack (i.e. devs). The alternative to install from sdist breaks editable installs, which I think are a very important part of the workflow for people that use devstack to develop openstack. While I acknowledge that editable installs in generally may have their days numbered, I definitely don't want us to break that important aspect of devstack just to sidestep this git thing if there are better alternatives (like this patch blessing each of our repos).

I think we need to be looking for a quick (interim?) solution to avoid everything being held up while we restructure how we do things in devstack (if that's even going to happen) and this seems reasonable. Can we roll this in to a stable and move from older to newer to avoid having to make grenade non-voting? Or perhaps the quickest way to at least get devstack jobs working again is to just do the latter.
Need to make grenade jobs non-voting to get it merge.
lgtm, holding +W until greande jobs are green which needs to wait until we backport it in reverse order or make them non voting.

functions-common.message: Not sure we can call it a "workaround". It's a proper fix, targeting subset of directories.
right. a "correct" solution would be to use virtualenv or something like that, preventing the root thingy. But that's more for the future. Sooo yeah. "workaround without a hack" :).
It's a workaround in the sense that we're not (with this patch) completely changing how devstack works to fit git's new requirements. But agree, it's better than a hack :)
I wonder if --system makes more sense. But currently we're only experiencing this as root when running the pip installs so sudo + --global should be sufficient.

Turns out not! On bionic git-config will end up writing to ~stackuser/.gitconfig instead of ~root/.gitconfig unless sudo is run with -H.

However, --system is better I think because it's more discoverable when you're trying to clean a system. The ~root/.gitconfig is decidedly more hidden, especially on distros where logging in as root is unusual.

Is this the actual problem? If so, what client is generating URLs like this? If you instead do:

    requests.get('http://localhost:9292/v2/images', params={'name': u'\u041f\u0420\u0418\u0412\u0415\u0422'})

You shouldn't get a URL constructed like that and this issue shouldn't arise. Any *good* HTTP client won't behave this way unless you hardcode the URL. It's my opinion that anyone hard-coding the URL deserved any unhelpful error code they get. Ideally it won't be a 500 error code, but that's a different matter.
According to the bug report, this is a possible URL based on something taking a query string with a unicode object name.

specs/version11.0/allowed-address-groups.message:
Another alternative could be to implement "allowed_cidrs_groups" in Octavia.
I.e. reusable groups, per project, across LBs.
Yes, same. Then they are shareable even outside of Octavia. For example, we have users that utilize them for VMs already as well.
Makes sense. But since Octavia already can talk to Neutron and the latter has the address group feature implemented, personally I'd prefer reusing it.
We need to decide here how this will be persisted. Do you plan to create another DB table like allowed_cidrs did? (hint: says yes and add it to the spec).
Right, I was hoping "handled identically to allowed_cidrs" would cover that, but I can go copy/paste the section from that spec here. :D

Can you describe the intended API behavior if the user specifies both allowed_cidrs and allowed_address_groups?
Will they merge in some way? can there be a conflict?

For amphora-provider which uses Neutron security groups, yes both should be supported. One security group can contain some rules with remote-cidr and others with remote-address-group. In the firewall driver backend (OVS for instance), cidrs will be merged to generate the firewall rules. There shouldn't be conflict as the final access rules will be the union of allowed_cidrs and allowed_address_groups.

Right, they can very easily co-exist and will essentially just be merged together. Really, Address Groups are just a list of CIDRs stored elsewhere and linked in, so it's a union of the two things. I'll note this explicitly.
This section should probably mention what data you will pass to the provider driver at API create time.
Yeah I guess this is a reasonable place for it.

nit: Technically this isn't over REST, it's part of the octavia-lib library drivers get access to and works over a socket behind the scenes.
https://github.com/openstack/octavia-lib/blob/master/octavia_lib/api/drivers/driver_lib.py#L164
Ah, shows how out of the loop I am. Maybe need to reorganize this then.

It's worthy to note that one "allowed address group" will be bound to one security group rule. And one address group can contain multiple CIDRs and can be updated anytime by the user using the Neutron API.
For this feature, with the amphora provider, deployers will need to make sure the "address_groups" extension is enabled in neutron.

yes, good call. And the exact Neutron API extension we want to check is "security-groups-remote-address-group" https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/security_groups_remote_address_group.py#L16
Ah good catch, thanks. I'll add that note.

Somewhere in here, we need to talk about what the behavior will be if the address_group extension is missing or disabled in neutron.
https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/master/octavia/network/drivers/neutron/base.py#L54
I assume the Octavia API call will be rejected.
Yeah, I believe there is precedent for this, and I think you are correct. We would just reject the request with a useful error message.

1st issue: ✔
2nd issue: in the past the stable policy required that branches should be EOL'd branch-by-branch, so that it is clearly visible for a project which branches are open and which are not, thus makes the (branch-by-branch) backporting clear and easy to follow. it could make less easy to follow from user perspective if projects would decide keeping open different stable branches and EOL'ing other branches. for a project that is maintained for multiple project this is trivial, though i understand that TripleO is only (considered to) consumed by Red Hat. Anyway, I don't want to block it, i only think it's better to keep things in sync with OpenStack way of working. So if stable/ussuri is going to EOL then so should go stable/train, too, for TripleO.

Thanks Marios. Before we continue with this patch, can you confirm that all the unnecessary job definitions were removed from project-config and other repositories (if there were any - based on the eol process 2nd step [1]).

On the other hand I strongly advise that do not skip any branch from the EOL line, as that could confuse consumers of OpenStack. I understand that TripleO is used by Red Hat only and the team chose to keep open Train as that is the supported branch by Red Hat, though since it's open source, anyone could use it. Nevertheless, if it is considered Red Hat only, maintained only by Red Hat, then it could be supported via downstream only as well. So I'm rather see either option out of these two:

1. if stable/train is not EOL'd upstream, then keep it open for stable/ussuri as well
2. if stable/ussuri is EOL'd upstream, then EOL stable/train as well.


[1] 'Remove any related zuul jobs that are defined in other repositories and not needed anymore.' -- https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#end-of-life

yes, I know that, i didn't even say that tripleo follows it :) anyway, I understand (and understood even before I asked the question) TripleO points, but wanted to call your attention that this is not fortunate and hoped that we could keep things consistent in community o:) If this discussion would come up on a different (core) project, maintained by multiple vendors, then I would strictly say NO and would ask for a wider discussion on the topic... but I don't want to block this, so I'm also accepting this now for TripleO. Hashes are from the tip of the stable/ussuri branches, patch looks OK to me. Let's merge this.
also forgot to note we don't follow stable policy...

2nd issue is about the eol - so are you objecting to this going eol because train is not yet eol? Yes we are keeping train for a little longer.

but please clarify are you blocking this?

Suggested wording:

The neutron-api charm has a new configuration option: ``uplink-status-propagation``

This option allows the PF (physical function) link status for an OpenStack SR-IOV port on the host to be propagated to the VF (virtual function) link status on a cloud instance. To enable this, set the option to 'true' and assign attribute 'propagate_uplink_status' to the SR-IOV port during its creation (via flag ``--enable-uplink-status-propagation``).

.. note::

 This feature is available starting with OpenStack Stein.

What do you mean by 'automatic' - the charm now has an option to enable it (add this attribute to the port) or disable it - so the --enable-uplink-status-propagation will not work with neutron API requests.
